Project.Brief history of your project and organi: Satellogic is a company to make satellite images affordable and easy to use. It builds and launches its own satellites to take detailed pictures of Earth. Over the years, it grew from small test satellites to a large fleet with more than 50 satellites in orbit. To support science and technology, Satellogic created the EarthView project, a huge set of free satellite images. The dataset includes millions of pictures taken across many continents. The images are open for anyone to use, especially for research and building AI tools. This project shows Satellogic’s goal to share knowledge and make Earth data more accessible to everyone.
Project.Describe the data being stored onto File: The Satellogic EarthView project stores high-resolution satellite imagery data. This includes multi-spectral images (red, green, blue, and near-infrared bands) with approximately one-meter ground resolution, captured by Satellogic’s constellation of Earth-observing satellites. The dataset covers millions of regions across five continents and contains over seven million images collected. Each image includes metadata such as sun angles and satellite viewing geometry, supporting accurate analysis. The data, provided in cloud-optimized GeoTIFF format, enables applications in environmental monitoring, urban planning, and precision agriculture. Researchers also use it to train and validate AI models for remote sensing.
Project.How do you plan to prepare the dataset: To prepare the Satellogic EarthView dataset, we first download the high-resolution multi-spectral imagery (RGB and NIR bands) from AWS S3, verifying file integrity against the provided metadata. The imagery, delivered in Cloud-Optimized GeoTIFF (COG) format, is validated for consistency and organized by region and capture date. Using go-graphsplit, the files are segmented into manageable chunks and packaged into CAR files, with each file assigned a unique PieceCID. To ensure efficient retrieval, metadata such as file size, image bands, capture timestamps, and chunk counts are indexed and stored in a PostgreSQL database. Additional metadata like sun angles and satellite off-nadir angles are also preserved for scientific use. The CAR files are then submitted to selected Filecoin Storage Providers via go-graphsplit's deal-making API, enabling decentralized storage. This approach ensures the EarthView dataset is stored in a verifiable, retrievable, and long-term accessible manner.
Project.In which geographies do you plan on maki: Asia other than Greater China, Greater China, Europe
